questions.prompt: Why do compilers use intermediate representations?
options: To decouple front-end from back-end and enable optimization
IRs are required by language standards
questions.explanation: IRs provide a common representation enabling front-end/back-end separation and machine-independent optimization.

options: IR where each instruction has at most three operands
questions.explanation: Three-address code uses instructions of the form x = y op z, with at most two sources and one destination.

options: A maximal sequence of instructions with one entry and one exit
questions.explanation: A basic block is a maximal sequence of straight-line code with no branches except at entry and exit.

questions.prompt: What is a control flow graph (CFG)?
options: A directed graph of basic blocks showing control flow
questions.explanation: A CFG is a directed graph where nodes are basic blocks and edges represent control flow between them.

questions.prompt: What distinguishes high-level IR from low-level IR?
options: High-level preserves more source structure; low-level is closer to machine code
questions.explanation: High-level IRs retain source-like constructs; low-level IRs are closer to target machine operations.

questions.prompt: What is Static Single Assignment (SSA) form?
options: Each variable is assigned exactly once in the program text
questions.explanation: In SSA form, each variable has exactly one definition (assignment) in the static program text.

questions.prompt: What is a phi (Ï†) function in SSA?
options: A function that selects a value based on control flow path taken
questions.explanation: Phi functions merge values at control flow join points, selecting the value from the incoming edge taken.

questions.prompt: Where are phi functions placed in SSA form?
options: At dominance frontiers of variable definitions
questions.explanation: Phi functions are placed at dominance frontiers, where multiple definitions of a variable may reach.

questions.prompt: What is a major benefit of SSA form for optimization?
options: Explicit def-use chains simplify many analyses
questions.explanation: SSA makes def-use relationships explicit, simplifying optimizations like constant propagation and dead code elimination.

options: Converting back to non-SSA form by eliminating phi functions
questions.explanation: SSA destruction converts SSA to conventional form by replacing phi functions with copies.

options: A typed, SSA-based IR used by LLVM compilers
questions.explanation: LLVM IR is a typed, SSA-based intermediate representation used throughout the LLVM compiler infrastructure.

questions.prompt: What is the difference between quadruples and triples in three-address code?
options: Quadruples store result name; triples use instruction position
questions.explanation: Quadruples explicitly name the result; triples reference results by instruction number (position).

options: Translating high-level constructs to lower-level operations
questions.explanation: IR lowering transforms high-level operations (like array access) into sequences of simpler operations.

questions.prompt: What is a dominator in a control flow graph?
options: A block through which all paths to another block must pass
questions.explanation: Block A dominates block B if every path from entry to B goes through A.

questions.prompt: Why might a compiler use multiple IR levels?
options: Different optimizations work better at different abstraction levels
questions.explanation: Multiple IR levels allow optimizations appropriate to each abstraction level (high-level restructuring, low-level register work).
